block.p: Problem With Certified Mail Causes Delays in Delivery Local postmasters have acknowledged that a failure to assign enough workers to move the mail and problems installing a computer system for tracking certified mail have led to pileups of letters -- which include tax payments, legal documents like foreclosure notices and court filings -- in postal warehouses.

In New York City, hundreds of taxpayers were sent notices demanding penalties and interest for failing to make June property tax payments on time before the city discovered what had happened. [Page A1.]

Without Napster, the Swap Goes On A decision by a judge to prohibit Napster from offering access to songs whose copyrights are owned by the major record labels is being viewed as a serious blow to those who had hoped to build a business on the online trading of copyrighted music. But the cultural phenomenon shows no signs of abating. [A1.]
Lawyers for Napster asked a federal court to stay a preliminary injunction, asserting it would effectively shut down the service. [C2.]

WorldCom Shares Fall on Warning WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, reported a 53 percent rise in second-quarter earnings, matching Wall Street expectations. But the company also warned that sales growth for the rest of the year would be at the low end of its previous estimate, and WorldCom shares tumbled as much as 15 percent before recovering somewhat. Shares of WorldCom ended the day down $5.4375, or 12 percent, at $39.3125. [C2.]

Nasdaq Plunges, but Dow Climbs Stocks were mixed as concern about the results of technology companies led investors to switch to old economy shares. The Nasdaq composite index fell 145.49 points, or 3.7 percent, to 3,842.23, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.80 points, to 1,449.62. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 69.65 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,586.13. [C8.]

Ex-Federated Chief Joins Penney Allen L. Questrom, who headed Federated Department Stores for much of the 1990's and led Barneys New York out of bankruptcy, was named chairman and chief executive of J. C. Penney, whose shares rose 16 percent. [C19.]
15 From Blair Indicted in Fraud Case D.H. Blair, a defunct Manhattan brokerage firm, and 15 of its officers and employees were indicted on securities fraud charges. [C6.]

Phone Giant Prepares to Lobby Deutsche Telekom is considering ways to reduce the German government's stake in the company as it prepares to wage a behind-the-scenes political battle to win approval of its plan to buy VoiceStream Wireless, said Ron Sommer, the company's chief executive. The holdings could be lowered either through other acquisitions, which would dilute the stake, or through a sale of shares. [C4.]

U.S. Reaches Deal on Web Privacy The government reached agreement with a group of Internet advertisers on how they will glean information from Web surfers and what they will do with it. Advertising. [C6.]

Ford Attributes Change to Research Ford Motor said that its market research, not the gut instinct of executives, prompted the company's decision to improve the gas mileage of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over five years. [C3.]
Hearst Wins Ruling in Paper Deal A federal judge in San Francisco ruled that the Hearst Corporation's $660 million purchase of The San Francisco Chronicle did not violate antitrust laws. [A18.]
